questions.question: A patient presented with vaginal bleeding following 6 weeks of amenorrhoea. Her UPT waspositive. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of first-trimester abortion which is most commonlycaused by chromosomal abnormalities.Autosomal trisomies are the most common (50%) genetic abnormality overall. Of these, the mostcommon trisomy involved in abortions is trisomy 16. Turner syndrome (monosomy X) is thesingle most common chromosomal abnormality in miscarriages.Causes of spontaneous abortion are:• Genetic -• Numerical chromosomal abnormalities• Chromosomal rearrangements•Mendelian etiology• Endocrine -• Luteal phase defects•Thyroid abnormalities• Diabetes mellitus.• Anatomical -• Cervical incompetence•Congenital uterine malformations• Uterine fibroid• Uterine synechiae•• Infectious (TORCH infections)• Immunological -• Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome• Autoimmunity• Maternal illness -• Cyanotic heart diseases• Hemoglobinopathies• Environmental -• Radiation exposure• Alcohol•• Cigarette smoking358

questions.question: A patient presented with a spontaneous abortion at 7 weeks of gestation. Which of thefollowing is the least likely chromosomal abnormality that can lead to this condition?
questions.explanation: The least likely chromosomal abnormality involved in first-trimester abortions is trisomy 1.The most common chromosomal abnormality in first trimester abortions is trisomy. The commontrisomies are:• Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18)•• Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)• Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)•• Trisomies 16 and 22Turner syndrome (Monosomy X) is the single most frequent chromosomal abnormality. It usuallyresults in abortion.

questions.question: Recurrent miscarriage is the loss of:
questions.explanation: Recurrent miscarriage is defined as ≥3 consecutive pregnancy losses at ≤ 20 weeks or with a fetalweight <500 g.It can be of 2 types:• Primary recurrent miscarriage where there are multiple losses in a woman who has neverdelivered a liveborn• Secondary recurrent miscarriage where multiple pregnancy losses occur in a patient who has hada prior live birth

questions.question: Which of the following conditions does not usually cause recurrent miscarriages?
questions.explanation: Infections do not usually cause recurrent miscarriages.Common causes of recurrent miscarriage:• Parental chromosomal abnormalities• Anatomical factors -•• Uterine synechiae or Asherman syndrome• Uterine leiomyomas• Congenital genital tract anomalies•Immunological factors -•Antiphospholipid antibody syndromeEndocrine factors -361• Luteal phase defect• Polycystic ovarian syndrome

questions.question: A primigravida had a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks. On examination, the fetus wasmorphologically normal. Further investigations were performed upon the patient's insistenceand the results are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given lab findings are suggestive of anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome (APLS).Criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:Clinical criteria -• Obstetric• Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks• One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks• Severe pre-eclampsia necessitating delivery before 34 weeks•• Vascular• One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organLaboratory criteria -• Presence of lupus anticoagulant• Presence of IgG or IgM anti-cardiolipin antibodies• Presence of IgG or IgM anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodiesAt least one clinical and one laboratory criteria is needed for the diagnosis.Non-specific tests for lupus anticoagulant are increased aPTT, Kaolin clotting time, and diluteRussell viper venom time.

questions.question: A woman comes to the casualty at 18 weeks of gestation with complaints of vaginal bleeding.She has a history of two early pregnancy losses. USG reveals the absence of fetal cardiacactivity. Which of the following investigations need not be done in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent abortions, and extensive infection workup isnot done.Even though recurrent abortions are defined as ≥3 pregnancy losses, investigations must be doneafter 2 consecutive losses.Diagnostic evaluation of recurrent pregnancy loss based on etiology is given as follows:Etiology Diagnostic evaluationGeneticParental karyotypingAnatomicHysterosalpingographyUltrasoundSaline-infusion sonography362Etiology Diagnostic evaluationEndocrineInfectiousAutoimmuneTSHTesting for insulin resistanceSerum prolactin levelOvarian reserve testingAntithyroid antibodiesNo evaluation is recommended unless the patient has evidence of chronic endometritis/cervicitis on examination, oris immunocompromisedAnticardiolipin antibody levels (IgG and IgM)Lupus anticoagulantHomocysteineFactorV LeidenProthrombin promoter mutationActivated protein C resistance

questions.question: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to haveantiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.explanation: The best mode of treatment for a pregnant woman with antiphospholipid syndrome(APS) isaspirin and heparin.APS is a prothrombotic disorder (autoantibody-mediated thrombophilia) affecting both arterialand venous systems.Patients present with recurrent pregnancy loss due to thrombosis of uteroplacental vessels, poorplacental perfusion, and prevention of normal decidual changes after zygote implantation. Theymay also present with preterm delivery, pre-eclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR),and fetal death.Criteria for APS include:•⚫ at least one otherwise unexplained fetal death at or beyond 10 weeks;•⚫ at least one preterm birth before 34 weeks gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia,placental insufficiency; or• at least three unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks.Aspirin (60-80mg daily) with heparin (5000-10,000 U subcutaneously every 12h) is the mosteffective therapy for APS. Treating APS with only aspirin (option A) is not recommended asheparin is crucial in preventing thrombus formation at the decidual-thrombotic interface,Corticosteroids (option C, D) should not be used in primary APS (without an associatedconnective tissue disorder) but are indicated in patients with pre-existing systemic lupuserythematosus (SLE) and APS (secondary APS).

questions.question: A G3A3 patient was admitted to the hospital with catastrophic APLS following a spontaneousabortion. Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.A: It is a rapidly progressive thromboembolic disorder
options.B: At least 2 organ systems should be involved to make a diagnosis
options.C: Infections can act as a trigger
options.D: IVIG can be used for treatment

questions.explanation: 363Catastrophic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (CAPS) is a complication of APLA syndrome, inwhich ≥3 organ systems are involved. It is also known as Asherson syndrome.It is seen in both primary and secondary APLA syndrome. Triggering factors include infections,trauma, and obstetric causes. IVIG can be used in CAPS when the first-line therapies with aspirinand heparin have failed.Note: Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition characterised by formation of intrauterineadhesions or synechiae.

questions.question: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

options.C: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
options.D: Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.explanation: Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painlesscervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products ofconception can also be seen.Risk factors for cervical incompetence:•Congenital uterine anomalies•Acquired -• Dilatation and currettage• Dilatation and evacuation• Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix•Amputation of cervix• Multiple gestations• Prior preterm birth

questions.question: Which of the following increase the risk of developing cervical incompetence?
questions.explanation: In-utero exposure to DES, twin pregnancy, and bicornuate uterus increase the risk of cervicalincompetence.Offsprings born to pregnant mothers who were treated with diethylstilbestrol may developcervical hypoplasia and malformation. They may also present with cervical incompetence duringtheir 2nd trimester.Cervical incompetence can be seen following MTP with surgical methods and not with medicalmethods.The retentive power of the internal os may be compromised by anatomical abnormalities likebicornuate uterus and overdistended uterus due to twin gestations.Risk factors for cervical incompetence:•Congenital uterine anomalies• Acquired -364• Dilatation and currettage• Induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation•Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix•• Amputation of cervix• Multiple gestations• Prior preterm birth

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her pastobstetric history was significant for 2 mid-trimester abortions. On USG, cervical length was20 mm and no bulging membranes were seen. What is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence. It can be managed withprophylactic cervical cerclage done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation.Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only bedone when there is bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix.Investigations for cervical incompetence:• In interconceptional period -•Passage of number 6 - 8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain• Funnel-shaped shadow in premenstrual hysterocervicography• During pregnancy -•• Per speculum examination showing cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes• USG revealing cervical length <2.5 cm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm

It can be done up to 24 weeks of gestation.Contraindications to cervical cerclage are:• Absolute.• >24 weeks of gestationActive labourActive vaginal bleedingAbruptio placentaPremature rupture of membranesChorioamnionitis• Severe uterine irritability• Fetal death or defect• Relative366• Prolapsed membranes•• Vaginal spotting

questions.question: A woman with cervical incompetence is posted for prophylactic McDonald's cerclage. Whichof the following statements is false about this procedure?

options.A: Removal of stitch must be done by 37th week
options.B: A mersilene tape is tied around the cervix
options.C: Done at the level of internal os

questions.explanation: In McDonald's cerclage, a nonabsorbable suture, such as Mersilene, is placed as a purse-stringsuture as high as possible at the level of the internal os, positioned at the junction where therugose vaginal epithelium transitions to the smooth vaginal portion of the cervix, below thebladder.Another cerclage procedure is Modified Shirodker's technique. In this, a non-absorbable(mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and is tiedposteriorly.Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case ofpreterm labour.•Complications of cervical cerclage:⚫ Slipping of suture• Chorioamnionitis• Rupture of membranes• Abortion or preterm labour• Cervical laceration or scarring

questions.question: A patient with contraceptive failure requires MTP at 5 weeks of gestation. You plan to use amedical method of abortion in her case. Which of the following is not a contraindication forthis?
questions.explanation: Chronic diabetes mellitus is not a contraindication to medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)with medical methods.Contraindications to medical methods of abortion are:•• Women with in situ intrauterine device• Severe anemia, coagulopathy, or anticoagulant use• Long term corticosteroid therapy••Severe liver, renal, pulmonary, or cardiovascular diseaseInherited porphyria• Uncontrolled hypertensionContraindications to surgical methods of abortion are:• Suction and evacuation - uterine size >10 weeks• Intrauterine instillation of hypertonic solution - cardiovascular or renal lesion and severeanaemia

questions.question: You have performed MTP on a multigravida at 10 weeks of gestation. As a part of post-opadvice, you must prescribe her a prophylactic antibiotic. Which of the following drugs wouldyou prefer?
questions.explanation: Doxycycline is the preferred drug for post-abortal antibiotic prophylaxis in this case. Oraldoxycycline 100 mg is given 1 hour before surgical evacuation. 200 mg is given after theprocedure is complete.The best method of MTP at 7-12 weeks is by suction and evacuation. Following this procedure,antibiotic prophylaxis is given with doxycycline.

questions.question: You are about to administer misoprostol to a woman who requires MTP in the 8th week ofher pregnancy. What is the dose of this drug when given by the mucosal route, according toWHO guidelines?
questions.explanation: Misoprostol is given at a dose of 800 mcg by mucosal route for MTP.Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal sideeffects. Hence, it is preferred over oral administration.WHO guidelines for medical management in induced abortion for <12 weeks of gestation:• Combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual misoprostol• Misoprostol only regimen (alternative): 800 µg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually,or buccally

questions.question: 355A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever,severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her mother revealed that shehad had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and RR was 36 breaths/ minute. Which of the following isnot a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) following septicabortion. Escherichia coli can be detected in septic abortion, but it is not a causative agent forTSS.Organisms causing toxic shock syndrome in septic abortion:• Streptococcus pyogenes• Clostridium perfringens• Clostridium sordelliiClinical features of septic abortion:• Fever with chills and rigors••• Abdominal or chest painDiarrhoea and vomiting• Renal angle tenderness⚫ Offensive purulent vaginal discharge.Clinical grading of septic abortion:• Grade I - infection localized in the uterus• Grade II - infection spreads to parametrium, tubes, ovaries, or pelvic peritoneum• Grade III - generalized peritonitis, endotoxic shock, jaundice, or acute renal failureEmpirical antibiotic therapy in septic abortion is started for the broadest microbial coverage.Piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem and clindamycin are given intravenously. Antibiotics canbe changed once culture sensitivity reports are available.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for stillbirth?

options.B: Illicit drug abuse by the mother

questions.explanation: An untreated seizure disorder in pregnancy is not a risk factor for stillbirth. However, the use ofcertain anti-epileptic drugs like valproate could lead to the development of neural tube defects inthe baby.Recent studies haven't consistently shown that untreated women with epilepsy face a higher risk,though it's hard to rule out entirely because those who manage without medication usually havemilder symptoms. Recent research found that birth defects were more common in children ofwomen who used anticonvulsants.Risk factors for stillbirth are:• Advanced maternal age•African-American race•Smoking• Illicit drug use370• Maternal medical diseases - overt diabetes or chronic hypertension• Assisted reproductive technology•Nulliparity•Obesity-• Previous adverse pregnancy outcomes prior preterm birth or IUGRNote: Stillbirth rates appear to be slightly increased in pregnancies conceived via assistedreproductive technology.
